qas.question: For how long did Robert Walpole serve as prime minister?
What party did Walpole belong to?
What concept took shape during Walpole's tenure as prime minister?
What would a minister have to do if he did not publicly support a cabinet policy?
Who is another prime minister who reiterated the principles of cabinet solidarity?
Who was the prime minister in the 17th century?
Who waited 21 years to become Prime minister?
Who's opponents packed the House of Commons?
Who did the monarch declare could see him in private?

context: From 1721 this was the <a1_0>Whig<a1_0/> politician <b5_0><b6_0><b7_0>Robert Walpole<b7_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/>, who held office for <a0_0>twenty-one years<a0_0/>. Walpole chaired cabinet meetings, appointed all the other ministers, dispensed the royal patronage and packed the House of Commons with his supporters. Under Walpole, the <a2_0>doctrine of cabinet solidarity<a2_0/> developed. Walpole required that no minister other than himself have private dealings with the king, and also that when the cabinet had agreed on a policy, all ministers must defend it in public, or <a3_0>resign<a3_0/>. As a later <b8_0>prime minister<b8_0/>, <a4_0>Lord Melbourne<a4_0/>, said, "It matters not what we say, gentlemen, so long as we all say the same thing."
